items.title: Does EMB works for regression?
Export complete dashboard to HTML file
items.body:
Hi, it would be nice if I could export a dashboard (i.e. list of visualizations) to an HTML file, such as in the below example. Looks like the necessary code is in python/interpret-core/provider/visualize.py.

```
from interpret.glassbox import ExplainableBoostingClassifier
from interpret import show, preserve

ebm = ExplainableBoostingClassifier()
ebm.fit(X_train, y_train)
ebm_global = ebm.explain_global(name='EBM')
ebm_local = ebm.explain_local(X_test, y_test)

# Below displays a dashboard inline in a Jupyter lab notebook with a link to expand to another window
# such as (127.0.0.1:7060/12345678/index.html) 
show([ebm_global, ebm_local])

# Below command does not work with a list, only with an individual visualization, and does not 
# display in a dashboard format
preserve([ebm_global, ebm_local], file_name='dashboard.html')
```

items.title: how to extract the data point of partial dependence plots.
items.body:
pdp = PartialDependence(predict_fn=gd.predict, data=X_test)
pdp_global = pdp.explain_global(name='Partial Dependence')
show(pdp_global)
I want to only  plot the main line of partial dependence. The rest background lines are confusing.
How to extract the data point of partial dependence plots and plot the only main line?

items.title: Interaction detection is much slower than the original GA2M
items.body:
Hey,

I am comparing the results and computation time between the current python-based interpret EBM and the previous Java based GA2M, and the current implementation seems to take an order of magnitude more than the Java implementation (and the time increases with more interactions).

Am I doing something wrong? I thought this implementation is faster than the original GA2M.

To reproduce:
```

import sys
import os
import time
import numpy as np
from sklearn.metrics import average_precision_score
from interpret.glassbox import ExplainableBoostingRegressor

X_train = np.random.rand(1000, 3)
y_train = X_train[:, 0] * X_train[:,1]

file = open('data.attr', 'w')
for i in range(3):
  file.write('X_train{}: cont\n'.format(i))
file.write('label: cont (target)')
file.close()
np.savetxt('data.train', np.concatenate((X_train, y_train.reshape(-1,1)), axis=1), delimiter=' ')


dataset_file = 'data.train'
datasetDisc = 'data_disc.train'
attset = 'data.attr'
attsetDisc = 'data_disc.attr'
residualPath = 'data.res'
modelPath = 'model.model'
FASTOutput = 'result.out'

start = time.time()
os.system("/usr/bin/java mltk.core.processor.Discretizer -i {} -o {} -t {} -r {} -m {}".format(dataset_file, datasetDisc, dataset_file, attset, attsetDisc))
os.system("/usr/bin/java mltk.predictor.tree.ensemble.brt.LSBoostLearner -t {} -m {} -o {} -r {} -V False".format(datasetDisc, 1000, modelPath, attsetDisc))
os.system("/usr/bin/java mltk.predictor.evaluation.Predictor -d {} -m {} -r {} -R {}".format(datasetDisc, modelPath, attsetDisc, residualPath))
os.system("/usr/bin/java mltk.predictor.gam.interaction.FAST -d {} -m {} -r {} -R {} -o {} -b 8".format(dataset_file, modelPath, attset, residualPath, FASTOutput))
end = time.time()

print('Java GA2M took {} seconds'.format(end - start))


start = time.time()
ebm = ExplainableBoostingRegressor(interactions = 1, random_state=42)
ebm.fit(X_train, y_train)
ebm_global = ebm.explain_global()
end = time.time()

print('interpret EBM took {} seconds'.format(end - start))


```
The result is

Creating threads...

items.title: extensions fail silently due to package mismatches
items.body:
the extension system can fail silently in some cases, for example if greenlet on the current system is an older version than what interpret depends on then the load() method will fail here:

https://github.com/microsoft/interpret/blob/master/python/interpret-core/interpret/ext/extension_utils.py#L42

however, on pip install the error message is not displayed anywhere, so the user has no idea that their classes are failing to load as extensions

items.title: Cited paper to GA2M is wrong?
items.body: ## Issue In `README.md`, there's a sentence as bellow: > * *EBM is a fast implementation of GA2M. Details on the algorithm can be found [here](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/KDD2015FinalDraftIntelligibleModels4HealthCare_igt143e-caruanaA.pdf).* ``` * *EBM is a fast implementation of GA2M. Details on the algorithm can be found [here](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/KDD2015FinalDraftIntelligibleModels4HealthCare_igt143e-caruanaA.pdf).* ``` In the above sentence, the paper "Intelligible Models for HealthCare: Predicting Pneumonia Risk and Hospital 30-day Readmission" is cited as details about the algorithm. However, the cited paper just describes applications of GA2M, not about the details, and I think the original paper that actually proposed GA2M in 2013 by Yin Lou, et al. should be linked. ## What to be Use `http://www.cs.cornell.edu/~yinlou/papers/lou-kdd13.pdf` instead of the current link. ``` * *EBM is a fast implementation of GA2M. Details on the algorithm can be found [here](http://www.cs.cornell.edu/~yinlou/papers/lou-kdd13.pdf).* ``` ## Ref - [Accurate intelligible models with pairwise interactions](https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2487579)

```
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
```

items.title: EBM parameter search with Ray Tune
items.body:
Hi!

I'm using Tune to search for optimal set of hyperparameters for different models. It works without issues for CatBoost and Keras models, however, I haven't been able to successfully run it with EBM on more than one CPU, let alone on GPU (it seems that EBM can't be run on GPU at all). When I haven't explicitly set `n_jobs=1`, I get this warning:

`UserWarning: Loky-backed parallel loops cannot be nested below threads, setting n_jobs=1`

Do you know is there something I'm missing or is it not possible to run EBM with Tune on multiple CPUs?

**Code to reproduce**
```
import ray
from ray import tune

ray.init(ignore_reinit_error=True)

import numpy as np
from interpret.glassbox import ExplainableBoostingClassifier

def train_ebm(config, reporter):
    n_samples = 100000
    x_train = np.random.rand(n_samples, 3)  # Random training data with 3 features
    y_train = np.random.randint(0, 2, n_samples)  # Random binary labels
    
    model = ExplainableBoostingClassifier(
        learning_rate=config['lr'], 
        n_jobs=12
    )
    
    model.fit(x_train, y_train)
    
    reporter()

ebm_experiment = tune.Experiment(
    name='ebm_test', 
    run=train_ebm, 
    num_samples=1,
    resources_per_trial={
        'gpu': 0,
        'cpu': 12
    },
    config={
        'lr': 0.01,
    }
)

trials = tune.run_experiments(ebm_experiment)
```

**Versions**
ray: 0.7.3
interpret: 0.1.15

items.title: interpretation of local feature importances
items.body:
Hi, 
thank you for this nice package. 

It would be helpful if the examples where extended with some documentation on how the visualized results are computed. 

For instance, what puzzles me is the computation of the local feature importance values in relation to the predicted value considering the Explainable Boosting Classifier. 

How do they relate to each other? Is there a relation between them (as the model is a GAM I would expect as a first guess some linear relation, but it doesn't add up)? 

My apologies if the question reveals some ignorance on my side to standard literature. 

Kind regards, 

Tomas

########## 
EDIT below: 

by try and error, I believe I found the solution: the probability score given by the Explainable Boosting Classifier is computed as:

 `
def compute_p(rs):
    return 1./(1. + np.exp(-rs))

t = np.sum(ebm_local._internal_obj['specific'][0]['scores']) + ebm_local._internal_obj['specific'][0]['extra']['scores']
p = compute_p(t)
`

items.title: OSError: exception: access violation reading 0x000002ABA0141000
items.body:
Hi dear InterpretML Team, 

I'm having this issue: OSError: exception: access violation reading 0x000002ABA0141000. This issue is with n_jobs=-1, when I set n_jobs=1 I got the same issue but access violation reading 0x0000026108C46000. I have no idea how to fix it. Seems that it comes from joblib! Here is what I'm trying to do on Jupyter notebook:

ebm = ExplainableBoostingClassifier(n_jobs=-1)
ebm.fit(x_train, y_train)
preds_interpret = ebm.predict_proba(x_test)

items.title: Question on Calibration
items.body:
I'm testing the classifier algorithm on a dataset (unfortunately confidential) with a binary target (70,000 rows and about 40 predictors) and seeing that while the rank ordering is competitive with other tree based methods, the predictions seem poorly calibrated - even on the training data itself. The prediction is always lower than the actual. **I am wondering if there might be a cause based on the algorithm that could be tuned or if this has been seen in development?**

The model is trained using the default settings (I have tweaked multiple parameters and not found any impact)

```
ebm = ExplainableBoostingClassifier(n_estimators=16,interactions=0,n_jobs=10)
ebm.fit(X,y)
```
The prediction is made on the training data. 
```
p=ebm.predict_proba(X)[:,1]
print(np.mean(p))  # THIS IS 0.023
```
I rank the predictions into deciles (10% bins) and plot the actual target rate and the mean prediction probability for each decile. The rank order is good, AUC is high (this is the training data of course) but we underpredict systematically. The red horizontal line is the overall mean of the training data which is significantly higher than the mean prediction noted above (0.1 versus 0.02)


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7504441/57897274-0fc06900-7822-11e9-822d-ebf91b6143ca.png)

items.title: Example of an interaction term from GA2M (a.k.a. EBM)?

If I use an explainable boosting classifier/regressor, how can I tell whether it considered interaction terms?

Can you document an example where interaction terms are used, including graphs?

Thanks.
